# Commit Messages

Explain what all has changed.
We love emojis ğŸš‚ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ§¶â®ï¸ğŸ“¦ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜
We use emojis in commit messages to make them more expressive and engaging. Hereâ€™s how we use them:
    x=major, y=minor, z=patch

examples:
    ğŸŒŸ FEAT: We want a good release. x.Y.z ...
or
    ğŸ› FIX: We fixed a bug in the code. x.y.Z ...
or
    ğŸ§¹ CHORE: We cleaned up the codebase. x.y.z ...
or
    ğŸš¨ BREAKING CHANGE: We made a change that breaks backward compatibility. X.y.z ...

We use semantic-release syntax for messaging.

- chore: (for changes that do not modify the public API, will not trigger a release)
- fix: (for bug fixes, triggers a patch release)
- feat: (for new features, triggers a minor release)
- BREAKING CHANGE: (in the body or footer, triggers a major release)

- Emojis add clarity and fun to commit messages. ğŸ˜„
- They help visually categorize the type of change. ğŸ·ï¸
- Emojis make scanning commit history faster and more engaging. ğŸ‘€
- They foster a positive, expressive team culture. ğŸ¤
- Emojis can highlight breaking changes or important updates. âš¡ï¸
- They make our project history more memorable and welcoming. ğŸ“š
